events.text:
...
The party spends all day following Mateo and talking with his friends.
It goes something like this:
[i]Mateo walks up to people’s houses, a friendly smile on his face.[/i]
[i]“Hey there!”[/i]
[i]“My friends here got pickpocketed in Honolulu recently. Have you seen this amulet before?”[/i]
[i]Mateo shows them a hand drawn picture of the amulet.[/i]
[i]“Or have any jobs or spare change to help them out?”[/i]
[i]The friend usually shakes their head.[/i]
[i]“Sorry, Mateo, I don’t have any money, nor have I seen that necklace. You’re better off asking someone else…”[/i]

[i]Mateo then cheerily moves on to the next friend, who essentially tells him the same thing.[/i]
[i]No one has spotted the amulet.[/i]
[i]No one has money to spare.[/i]
[i]No one has ideas to help them out.[/i]
Before you know it, it’s sundown.
I’m sorry I couldn’t help better…
Mateo looks sad for a moment, before a cheery smile returns to his face.

events.question: We’ll try again tomorrow! I’m determined to help you get out of Hawaii!

events.text: You really don’t have to help us.
Mateo smiles.

Oh, don’t worry.
If I were in your shoes, stranded in Hawaii with no money or connections, I would definitely need a stranger’s help to get back on my feet!
Still… you’re really going out of your way…
It’s my day off. I had nothing better to do!
You’ve helped so much.
Of course! It’s the least I can do.

events.choice: “I don’t think this method is helpful.”

events.text: Mateo’s smile freezes in place.
You… don’t?
Well, we did walk around all day and make zero progress on getting our money–
AND THE AMULET :(
–and the amulet back.
Mateo looks at his shoes.
… Oh. I understand.

events.question: I really thought some of my friends would be willing to help…

events.text: You pat Mateo on the back.
Raj nods.
Thank you, lad, for trying to help.

Young people like you are rare nowadays!
Never lose your kind sparkle, Mateo.
Mateo smiles again.
You must be tired. Come, you can stay at my place tonight!
Mateo happily leads you to his humble abode on the outskirts of the city.

His abode is small and homely, reminding you a bit of the Professor’s place. Unlike the Professor’s place however, Mateo’s home is [i]neat[/i]. The place is filled with books and stacks of paper with what looks to be… music notes? Music notes on them.
Mateo notices the line of your gaze and frantically covers it with a book, then moves between you and the papers.
Please, get comfortable! I’ll make you some food.
Mateo hurries off, a little flustered.
You, Raj, and the Professor are alone together again.
So.

events.question: How did you meet Mateo again?

events.text: [i]Meow.[/i]
Soot licks her paws.
Ah, I completely understand.
… Music?
Mateo does carry a guitar!
Yes, Howard, I had observed that as well.

[YOUR NAME] does.
He loved visiting the record shop on the weekends.

You nod, remembering all those fun times you spent in the record shop with the Professor.
Although the Professor wasn’t a music listener, he gave each and every one of your recommendations a listen.
You were never really a music person.
Oh.
I learned something new about you.
(singing) I was holding out for a hero ‘til the end of the night.
Raj blinks.
[i]What?[/i]
Just kidding.

Ha.
I really don’t understand your references, sometimes.
Well, most of the time.
I met him because of Soot. She chased a mouse who just so happened to run in the direction of Mateo.

Huh.
And Mateo just so happens to be a helpful guy.
At least, he tries.
It’s almost as if we met by fate, the moment “we needed a hero” to help us out in Hawaii.

Pfft.
Fate, yeah right.

You shrug.
Well, Raj has his beliefs.
Before you know it, Mateo has returned with food. You notice he gives each one of you a portion, but not himself.

events.question: He sits with you all, smiling.

events.text: Oh, me?
I’m not hungry.
Mateo smiles at you easily.
Mateo smiles easily.

Of course I am!
Why are you asking?
You’re not eating.
Oh, I’m not hungry.
Are you sure?
Mateo nods and drinks some water.

events.question: You think you hear a stomach growl.

events.text: Mateo nods.
I’m not hungry at all!
You shift closer to Mateo.

Wait, are you sure?
You must have been exhausted from traveling with me all day!
It’s the least I can do.
You’ve been helping us all day. You should eat. Come on. We’ll share.
Mateo smiles.
Alrighty, if you insist.
You and Mateo share.
Mateo leans forward after a few minutes of silent eating.

I’m really interested in your stories!
What brings you to Hawaii… and why do you need to go to India?
I [i]love[/i] hearing people’s stories.
Of course!

[i]The Professor dives into an explanation of your journey.[/i]
[i]To his research on beyuls, to Raj’s familial obligations, to you being the Professor’s assistant.[/i]
It takes a solid two hours for the Professor to explain everything in detail.
And that’s why we’re in Hawaii!
In summary, I need to go home, while Howard and [YOUR NAME] are chasing their dreams of finding the beyuls in Tibet.

Raj sighs.
Mateo tilts his head.
Do you have dreams, Raj?
Raj seems taken aback.
[i]Dreams[/i]?

Yeah. You know, ambitions. Things you want to accomplish in your life.
Like, I want to…
Mateo shakes his head.

Some may have the dream of becoming a world-renowned musician.
And no matter how impossible their dream sounds, they somehow achieve it.
They are the real protagonists of their stories.
But anyway… Do you have dreams, Raj? It sounded like you were contrasting yourself to the Professor and [YOUR NAME].

Oh, me?
…
O-Of course I do.
I enjoy researching the beyuls and the stories surrounding them.
That [i]is[/i] my research specialty at the University of Calcutta.

That’s so interesting!
Is that your dream, then?
Learning more about stories and beyuls?

Yes. But I wouldn’t call it a dream.
Dreams are called [i]dreams[/i] because they are largely considered unreachable.
I have already achieved my dreams. I research beyuls and their stories. It is an achievement, no longer a dream.
Mateo frowns.

But is there anything you’d like to still do with your research? The Professor and [YOUR NAME] seem to want to find the beyuls.
Do you want to find the beyuls too, Raj?
Raj looks at you and the Professor, but his gaze lingers on you.
I don’t have time for dreams.
Raj takes out an ornate ring from his pocket.
This is my engagement ring. I will be bound in a marriage for the rest of my life, where I would be obligated to start and raise a family, and assist my children with their dreams.
Raj sighs.

events.question: I’d rather save dreams for circumstances of certainty.

events.text: You won’t dream because you don’t feel in control of your life?
To strive for things that are uncertain now, but work towards the certainty in the future.
You wish you could give Raj a hug.
Anyway.

You smile at him.
Soot yawns.

Well, then. Let’s go to the city tomorrow and ask around for the amulet. Often, thieves pawn off stolen goods. Don’t worry, I know how to negotiate.
Get some rest.
The party rests for the night.
The next day, the party goes to Honolulu with Mateo.

As you walk through the busy streets of Honolulu, eyes peeled for the amulet–you spot it!
It’s being displayed at a stall in full glory.
THE AMULET!!!!!!
The Professor rushes to the stall.

YOUNG MAN.
THAT IS MY AMULET.
IT WAS STOLEN FROM ME JUST YESTERDAY, BY NAUGHTY PICKPOCKETS!
Please, do the kind deed and return it to me.
The shopkeeper looks at him with doubt.
No.
The Professor is devastated!
WHAT!?
Mateo hurries forward.
Hi there, my friend here really did lose his wallet [i]and[/i] his amulet here yesterday.
That’s a tried and true method of trying to get things for free. No, I’m not giving this to you for free. Now scram.

Come on, can you at least try to understand our situation? We’re travelers [i]stranded[/i] in Hawaii after thieves stole everything from us.
That amulet is really important to him. See? He’s crying.
[i]Sobs[/i]
You know, just for that, I’ll raise the price for trying to scam me.
Why, you–
Mateo slides between Raj and the shopkeeper.
Hey, hey. Let’s negotiate, if that’s okay?
I’m not lowering the price for you.
Okay, well, this is all I have.
Mateo counts his money in front of the shopkeeper.

…
Do you expect me to pity you?
[i]Grrr![/i]
You pet Soot to try and calm her down.
Okay. How about… I trade something of value for it?
Oh?
Mateo pulls his guitar out.
Can you assess this guitar’s value? Maybe it can cover the amulet’s price?
The shopkeeper takes the guitar and weighs it in his hands.
This is quite the antique!
The shopkeeper gives it a few discordant strums, and you see Mateo stiffen a bit. The shopkeeper nods in satisfaction.
This, and the money, should cover the necklace.
Mateo holds his hand out to shake.
You step in between the two of them, exasperated.

No, Mateo.
Don’t sell your guitar for our sake.
Please.
Mateo smiles.
But I really don’t mind! You are the ones in a pickle here, not me!
And besides, I haven’t been playing lately, and it’s just gathering dust…

No, please don’t do that!
You carry your guitar around with you everywhere you go. I [i]know[/i] you care about it. Please, [i]please[/i] don’t sell something you value so much for our sake!
Mateo’s smile wavers.
You’re stranded in Hawaii and the amulet is so important to the Professor–
[i]Sobs.[/i]
–I want to help you!
Don’t sell your guitar, we’ll find another way to get the amulet back…
But, [YOUR NAME]...
I…
Raj takes his engagement ring out and presents it to the shopkeeper!
How about this? Does this cover the cost?
The shopkeeper’s eyes bulge out of his head! He leans in with his glasses and examines it closely.

These gems! They are [i]real[/i]! Yes, yes–and yes!
This covers the necklace, and more, here–
The shopkeeper digs through his items and hands them [i]thick[/i] wads of cash, along with the amulet.

The Professor immediately hugs the amulet.
Raj counts the money.

This should be enough for tickets to Japan!
And more!

Here let me hold it for you.
People usually don’t steal from me.
But Raj.
Are you [i]sure[/i]? Wasn’t the ring important to you?
Well, my family will most certainly not be pleased…
But it would have been morally wrong to let Mateo sell his prized possession for a group of strangers he’d never see again.
Mateo smiles.
Thank you, [YOUR NAME], Raj.
he Professor abruptly embraces the three of you, plus Soot, in a grandfatherly hug.

THANK YOU ALL!
If it wasn’t for you, I wouldn’t have my amulet back!!
The Professor releases you from the hug.
Mateo smiles.
Of course! I love helping.
Raj flushes in embarrassment.

events.question: Y-Yeah, no problem, Howard. It wasn’t like I did anything big anyway.

events.text: Yeah!
Raj shifts awkwardly.
No, no–it was a team effort, [YOUR NAME]. I barely did anything.
Mateo beams at you.

Aww!
But it wasn’t all me, really, it was a team effort!
Let us go forth! Mateo, would you like to join us on our journey? You seemed very interested in beyuls–not a lot of young people are interested, and I would be very happy to take you under my wing!

events.question: I don’t want to impose! You’d be using your money on me…

events.text:
Mateo shifts his grip on his guitar, hiding it behind his back again.
Everyone has dreams, but Mateo hasn’t told you his.
Perhaps we can help you achieve it.
Mateo flushes.
I-I… thank you. You’re so kind.

You provided us with food and a place to stay when we had nothing.
If it weren’t for you, we’d be homeless!
And I know exactly what it feels like to be homeless…

But you gave us a home, even if it was just for one night—[i]thank you[/i], Mateo.
We want to extend it back to you.
Aww, you’re so sweet.

events.choice: “We want to get to know you better.”

events.text:
And because we like you, Mateo.
You’re kind, sweet, and charming. We would all like to get to know you better.
Ditto.
I agree!

And… it seems like you do have a dream you want to achieve.
Perhaps we can help you achieve it.
Mateo smiles.
Aww, you’re so kind.
I promise I’ll do my very best to help you all on your journey! I won’t be a nuisance or a burden at all. Together, we’ll find the beyuls!
Mateo pulls everyone into a hug.
Thank you [i]so much[/i].

You purchase the tickets and board the ship to Tokyo, Japan.
The rest of the day is blissfully peaceful.

As night falls, you stare at the silhouette of the Hawaiian islands.
Another land, behind you.
